source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_031_chunk5
evidence_span: Due to the large mass of the forged bar (8 in. diameter), beta quenching the long bars (Process A) would result in the least severe quench and the laboratory beta quenching with thin strips would be subjected to the most severe quench.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_031_chunk5
evidence_span: Billet quenching tends to be close to the bar quench.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_031_chunk5
evidence_span: Hollow beta quenching severity tends towards that of the laboratory quench.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_031_chunk5
evidence_span: The slower quench in the billet beta-quenched sample will increase the lath width and intermetallic particle size, while reducing particle number density, compared with the hollow beta-quenched sample (Fig. 11) in the as-quenched state.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_031_chunk5
evidence_span: The slower quench in the billet beta-quenched sample will increase the lath width and intermetallic particle size, while reducing particle number density, compared with the hollow beta-quenched sample (Fig. 11) in the as-quenched state.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_031_chunk5
evidence_span: The slower quench in the billet beta-quenched sample will increase the lath width and intermetallic particle size, while reducing particle number density, compared with the hollow beta-quenched sample (Fig. 11) in the as-quenched state.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_031_chunk5
evidence_span: Moreover, the slower cooling is also conducive to the formation of equilibrium intermetallic particles in the billet beta-quenched sample.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_031_chunk5
evidence_span: Also, the billet beta-quenched samples are exposed to at least two additional thermal treatment steps after the quench, viz., the hot extrusion and the first annealing after cold reduction (Figs. 1 and 11) compared with the hollow beta-quenched sample.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_031_chunk5
evidence_span: Thus the microstructure and intermetallic particles have significant opportunity to attain further equilibrium in the billet beta-quenched sample.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_031_chunk5
evidence_span: Comparing the billet beta quenching with the bar quenching (Process A), the nucleation rate of the intermetallic particles is expected to be higher in the former due to its higher cooling rate.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_031_chunk5
evidence_span: With the exception of the final recrystallization annealing of the samples subjected to the bar quenching, both the billet and bar quenched samples were exposed to the same thermal processing subsequent to the quench.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_031_chunk5
evidence_span: On this basis, both samples were expected to have similar volume fractions of intermetallic particles, as was observed to be the case.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_031_chunk5
evidence_span: The hollow quenched sample is expected to have the highest nucleation rate for the intermetallic particles among the three samples examined.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_031_chunk5
evidence_span: This led to the highest residual matrix solute content, lowest particle volume fraction, and partial retention of the interparticle Sn enrichment as well as the nonequilibrium, solute-rich particles expected from beta quench in this sample.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_031_chunk5
evidence_span: This led to the highest residual matrix solute content, lowest particle volume fraction, and partial retention of the interparticle Sn enrichment as well as the nonequilibrium, solute-rich particles expected from beta quench in this sample.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_031_chunk5
evidence_span: This led to the highest residual matrix solute content, lowest particle volume fraction, and partial retention of the interparticle Sn enrichment as well as the nonequilibrium, solute-rich particles expected from beta quench in this sample.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_031_chunk5
evidence_span: This led to the highest residual matrix solute content, lowest particle volume fraction, and partial retention of the interparticle Sn enrichment as well as the nonequilibrium, solute-rich particles expected from beta quench in this sample.

evidence_span: For the Process A Zircaloy-2 samples, the ternary particles were based on either Zr2Ni or ZrCr2, both of which are the equilibrium particles expected in the Zr-Ni and Zr-Cr systems, respectively.

evidence_span: in Zircaloy-2 a more significant refinement down to 1 5 nm (Fe/Cr ratio τ = 0 . 7 8 ) was achieved

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_031_chunk6
evidence_span: a more uniform distribution of particles with small interparticle spacing is desirable for providing several cathodic sites and thereby minimizing the chances for H 2 buildup at a given particle

evidence_span: testing in refreshed steam led to different results depending on quenching rate

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_031_chunk8
evidence_span: high weight gains are observed at low quenching rates from the beta

evidence_span: low weight gains persist even after long time annealing in the high alpha-range
